prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 CO (1-0) :NGC 1672 mosaic
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This peoject aims to investigate the physical properties giant molecular clouds in circunmuclear star-forming region of barred spiral galaxy NGC 1672. CO (1-0) spectral line will be used to detect and to estimate various properties of them. Since the circunmuclear star-forming ring is not much spatially extanded (20 x 20 arcsec), only a pointings of observation will be used to cover the field of interest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The main goal of this proposal is to survey individual giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in the circumnuclear star-forming ring (CNR) of NGC 1672 at the distance of 14.5 Mpc. The size of the CNR is 18" x 15" (1.26 kpc x 1.05 kpc) and we will map a region of 40" x 40" covering the CNR. We will detect GMCs and derive their physical properties such as CO luminosity, physical size, virial mass and CO to H_2 conversion faction (X_CO). The observational constraints and corresponding justification are as follows.
1. Receivers: CO(1-0) line (115 GHz) of Band 3 CO(1-0) is the fundamental mode in CO observations to trace molecular gas. Previous observations of the CNRs in other galaxies show that CO(1-0) lines are the brightest similarly in the nucleus and CNRs, while higher transition CO lines are brighter in the nucleus.
2. Angular resolution: 0.5" In order to derive physical properties of individual GMCs in NGC 1672, we need high signal to noise ratio (S/N > 5) and high angular resolution (~0.5") data set. We aim to derive virial mass of GMCs in the CNR like the Orion molecular cloud in the Milky Way with masses of 5x10^5 M_solar or larger. Several observational and theoretical studies showed that GMCs have virial radii of 15 ~ 20 pc (Blitz & Rosolowsky 2004, Fukui & Kawamura 2010). This physical size corresponds to an angular resolution of 0.5" at the distance of NGC 1672 (14.5 Mpc).
3. Pointing: a single pointing The size of the CNR is 18" x 15" (1.26 kpc x 1.05 kpc) and we will map a region of 40" x 40" covering the CNR centered on the galaxy center. The antenna beamsize estimated form the OT and the CASA is ~54". Therefore our target field can be covered with a single pointing.
4. Spectral resolution: 0.488 MHz (1.275 km/s) The velocity dispersion for typical GMCs with a mass of 5 x 10^5 M_solar is ~10 km/s (Blitz & Rosolowsky 2004). In order to resolve ~10 km/s line width, we need a spectral resolution of ~ 1 km/s. Thus we choose a spectral resolution of 0.488 MHz (1.275 km/s) and a bandwidth of 238 MHz in Band 3.
5. Spectral sensitivity: 3.7 mJy We aim to detect the CO(1-0) line flux emitting from the GMCs with M > 5 x 10^5 M_solar at the distance of 14.5 Mpc. Assuming the mean X_CO value of GMCs in the Milky Way (X_CO = 2 x 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1)^-1), the CO line flux is expected to be ~18 mJy. In order to detect this flux density with a S/N ~5 in the spectral resolution of ~1 km/s, we need 1 sigma noise level of ~3.7 mJy. About 40 minute exposure time is required for this pointing. The time on calibrators and overhead is ~40 minute. The total required time including the time on sources, calibrators, and overhead is ~1.3 hours.
6. Other setting Calibration: the default flux calibration provided by ALMA observation group is enough. Bandpass accuracy: we do not need exceptionally higher bandpass accuracy. Scheduling/time constraints: we do not have any special time constraints. Special constraints on standard observing modes: We need no special constraints.
7. A brief result of ALMA simulation We performed an ALMA simulation using the "simobserve" and "simanalyze" tasks in CASA. We run a "simobserve" task with: a) H_a image for NGC 1672 taken with the HST as an input skymodel image, b) 115 GHz as a incenter, c) 0.488 MHz as a inwidth, d) 2300s as a integration time, e) 0.5â€œ as a map size, f) alma.cycle2.7.cfg as a antennalist. We used default values for other parameters. The "simanalyze" task was executed with a default setting. The output PSF has a size of 5.3" x 4.5". It is comparable to the proposed angular resolution with ALMA and ~5 times broader than input HST image. Although the input image was smoothed out, it still shows star forming regions and fine large scale structures without severe noisy patterns. We expect that an ALMA observation of the CNR with proposed observing requirements will detect a number of GMCs and will allow us to derive their physical properties.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Circumnuclear rings in barred galaxies are a unique place to study star formation in high density environment. Gas, flowing along the bar, is accumulated to very high density in the ring, forming massive star clusters. We propose to map the circumnuclear ring in NGC 1672 which is a barred spiral galaxy, with a CO(1-0) line to study the GMCs in high density environment. Analyzing the HST images of this galaxy, we have found a number of young massive star clusters in the ring which are about two magnitude brighter than those in other regions. However, little is known about the properties of the GMCs in this ring. Main goals are 1) to detect individual GMCs with M > 5*10^5Msol in the circumnuclear ring, 2) to measure their CO luminosity and size, 3) to measure their velocity dispersion and derive their virial mass, 4) to estimate the CO-to-H2 conversion factor, and 5) to derive the mass function of the GMCs. These results will reveal whether the properties of GMCs in high density environments are different from those in normal environments or not, and will allow us to tell whether young massive clusters are formed via merging of normal GMCs or slow collapse of super GMCs.
